   Imaging:
   RUQ US
   FINDINGS: The liver shows no focal or textural abnormality. There is no
   biliary dilatation seen. A right pleural effusion is noted.
   DOPPLER EXAMINATION: The main portal vein, right portal vein and left
   portal
   vein are all patent with hepatopetal flow. Appropriate flow is seen in
   the
   hepatic veins and the IVC. The splenic vein and SMV are patent with
   flow
   toward the liver. Appropriate hepatic waveforms are seen in the main
   hepatic
   artery. Since the examination of one day prior, the previous reversal
   of
   flow in the right portal and splenic veins has resolved.
   IMPRESSION:
   1. Patent hepatic vasculature with appropriate flow directions.
   Previously
   present flow reversal in right portal vein and splenic vein has
   resolved and
   main portal venous hepatopetal flow is now demonstrated.
   2. No biliary dilatation.
   3. Right pleural effusion.
   CXR:
                        Preliminary Report !! PFI !!
   Low lung volumes.
   Per my read, increased diffuse haziness that is worse at bases.
   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]).
   - Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
   Keep transplant surgery abreast of any changes in mental status.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Following q6h INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs for the next
   12 hours, then consider spacing out.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  FSBGs have been low (44 and 72 and 70).
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal pain: Stable, pulsitile, diffuse abdominal pain could
   represent expected post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other
   intrabdominal inflammation (such as pancreatitis), v. developing
   infection (such as chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less
   likely given that pt is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is
   stable, and she has no vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds. Morphine 1mg q4h prn for pain, but only
   to be given if clear mental status.
   -          Continue to monitor symptom and physical exam, as well as
   vitals and WBC.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   -          Repeat vanc trough in AM given changing renal status amd
   re-dose as needed.
   - OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return of
   normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Vaginal
   bleeding is scant. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped an
   appropriate 3.5 points. Hct has declined just 1 point since then,
   confirming that there is no current brisk bleed.
   -          Continue to follow q6h hct.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows atelectasis, but no sign of
   pneumonia. Phanensteil incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts
   appear normal. U/A from [**8-20**] showed 147 WBC. Urine cx from [**8-19**] was
   negative, but an infection could have developed since then.
   -          Continue to follow WBC
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative. Urine cx from [**8-20**]
   is pending.
   -          f/u urine cx.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # Metabolic acidosis: Likely secondary to lactic acidosis from acute
   hepatic failure. ABGs show resolution: pH = 7.42.
   - D/c regular ABGs.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - d/c MgSO4, as she is now 48hrs post-delivery and hypermagnesemic
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   - Psych and SW evals today. They have been contact[**Name (NI) **].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Turn NG suction off. Advance diet as tolerated, as long as
   pt continues passing gas or having BMs and mental status is alert
   enough to allow for safe swallowing. Continue to follow electrolytes
   q6h today and replete as needed.
   Glycemic Control:  Finger sticks q2h. Amps of D50% for hypoglycemia.
   ADAT, as above.
   Lines:
   PIV x 2.
   A-line
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation. Incentive spirometry hourly. OOB as tolerated.
   Communication:  Mom and Dad in the hospital most of the day and night.
   Code status: Full.
   Disposition: ICU.

TITLE:
   24 Hour Events:
   Extubated w/o incident yesterday AM. Breathing comfortably on RA
   afterwards.
   RUQ US showed patent hepatic vasculature with appropriate flow
   directions, no biliary dilatation, R pleural effusion.
   INR recovering, therefore now taken off of xplant list. Blood bank was
   made aware, as they had been reserving blood for her.
   Renal decided not to dialyze. Will re-evaluate this AM.
   Ordered gentle pain meds, 1mg q6h and hold for any decline in mental
   status. Instructions not to give unless pt fully oriented or HO paged
   to avoid missing altered MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 384**] from liver failure.
   Received 1U pRBC for hct of 20 with tachycardia to 110s, per surgery
   recs.
   Desaturated to 86% in the setting of low glucose and grogginess. Put on
   6L by face tent and O2 sat increased into 90s. Off face tent sats
   around 90.
   Recurrent hypoglycemias, with FSBG of 44 and 72. Given 25mg D.
   Pt is not passing gas and has not had a BM since Thursday. Surgery
   commented that this is normal post-op, particularly given her
   immobility. Gave lactulose enema x 1
 stool and gas, which is
   continuing.

   of

   1. Patent hepatic vasculature with appropriate flow directions.

                        Preliminary Report !! PFI !!

   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]).
   - Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
   Keep transplant surgery abreast of any changes in mental status.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Following q6h INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs for the next
   12 hours, then consider spacing out.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  FSBGs have been low (44 and 72 and 70).
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal pain: Stable, pulsitile, diffuse abdominal pain could
   represent expected post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other
   intrabdominal inflammation (such as pancreatitis), v. developing
   infection (such as chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less
   likely given that pt is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is
   stable, and she has no vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds. Morphine 1mg q4h prn for pain, but only
   to be given if clear mental status.
   -          Continue to monitor symptom and physical exam, as well as
   vitals and WBC.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   -          Repeat vanc trough in AM given changing renal status amd
   re-dose as needed.
   - OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return of
   normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Vaginal
   bleeding is scant. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped an
   appropriate 3.5 points. Hct has declined just 1 point since then,
   confirming that there is no current brisk bleed.
   -          Continue to follow q6h hct.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows atelectasis, but no sign of
   pneumonia. Phanensteil incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts
   appear normal. U/A from [**8-20**] showed 147 WBC. Urine cx from [**8-19**] was
   negative, but an infection could have developed since then.
   -          Continue to follow WBC
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative. Urine cx from [**8-20**]
   is pending.
   -          f/u urine cx.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # Metabolic acidosis: Likely secondary to lactic acidosis from acute
   hepatic failure. ABGs show resolution: pH = 7.42.
   - D/c regular ABGs.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - d/c MgSO4, as she is now 48hrs post-delivery and hypermagnesemic
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   - Psych and SW evals today. They have been contact[**Name (NI) **].
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Turn NG suction off. Advance diet as tolerated, as long as
   pt continues passing gas or having BMs and mental status is alert
   enough to allow for safe swallowing. Continue to follow electrolytes
   q6h today and replete as needed.
   Glycemic Control:  Finger sticks q2h. Amps of D50% for hypoglycemia.
   ADAT, as above.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose.
* She underwent an emergency C-section due to pre-eclampsia and is currently recovering.
* The patient is experiencing hypoglycemia, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and liver failure.
* She has a history of depression and attempted suicide, but is currently not feeling suicidal.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Hepatic Encephalopathy:** The patient's liver failure may lead to encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, seizures, and even death.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient's immunocompromised state due to liver failure and potential infection may increase the risk of sepsis.
3. **Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):** The patient's respiratory failure may progress to ARDS, which can cause hypoxia and respiratory failure.
4. **Renal Failure:** The patient's acute renal failure may worsen and require dialysis.
5. **Infection:** The patient's compromised immune system and potential wound infection may lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
6. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's liver failure may cause gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, or bowel obstruction.
7. **Depression:** The patient's history of depression and current situation may lead to worsening depression and suicidal thoughts.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, mental status, and laboratory results.
2. Administer antibiotics to cover potential infections and adjust as necessary based on culture results.
3. Maintain close communication with the patient's family and mental health team to address any concerns or issues.
4. Consider transferring the patient to a liver transplant center if her condition worsens or if a transplant is deemed necessary.
5. Monitor for signs of hepatic encephalopathy and take prompt action if symptoms develop.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided progress note and may not include all relevant information. A more comprehensive evaluation and consultation with specialists may be necessary to fully assess the patient's condition and develop an effective treatment plan.

Summary:

The patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose and a recent emergency cesarean section for pre-eclampsia. She has been experiencing altered mental status, with confusion, impulsive behavior, and asterixis flap, which may be related to ammonia toxicity, hypoglycemia, or other factors. Her liver enzymes have been trending downward, but T-bili is still rising. She has been on N-acetylcysteine IV drip and vitamin K PO.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a rising creatinine level and low urine output. Her electrolytes are abnormal, with hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia. She has been experiencing respiratory failure, with decreased air movement and breath sounds at the bases, and is currently on oxygen by face tent.

The patient's hemoglobin level is low, likely due to a combination of post-partum, s/p c-section, dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. She has been transfused with PRBCs and is being monitored for signs of hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.

The patient's WBC count is elevated, likely due to an inflammatory reaction in the setting of hepatic failure. She has a positive U/A, but the urine culture was negative. She is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver enzymes are still rising, and T-bili is still increasing, which may indicate ongoing liver damage.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is rising, and her urine output is low, which may indicate ongoing kidney damage.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still tenuous, with decreased air movement and breath sounds at the bases, which may indicate ongoing lung damage.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient has been experiencing frequent hypoglycemic episodes, which may indicate ongoing liver damage or other factors.
5. Infection: The patient has a positive U/A, and her WBC count is elevated, which may indicate an ongoing infection.
6. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and is currently experiencing altered mental status, which may indicate ongoing depressive symptoms.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, which may indicate ongoing blood loss or bone marrow suppression.
8. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ABGs show resolution, but she may still be at risk for developing metabolic acidosis due to ongoing liver damage.

Plan:

1. Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
2. Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
3. Continue N-acetylcysteine IV drip until acetaminophen level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
4. Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolytes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
5. Continue q2h fingersticks and repletion with amps of D50.
6. Continue efforts to use local comfort measures and minimize pain meds.
7. Continue to monitor symptom and physical exam, as well as vitals and WBC.
8. Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures come back negative.
9. Repeat vancomycin trough in AM given changing renal status and re-dose as needed.
10. Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
11. Continue to follow WBC and f/u cultures.
12. Send a repeat U/A and urine cx.
13. D/c regular ABGs.
14. Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
15. Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement.
16. Treat breast engorgement with ice and compression.
17. Psych and SW evals today.
18. Continue prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer.

   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]).
   - Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
   Keep transplant surgery abreast of any changes in mental status.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Following q6h INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs for the next
   12 hours, then consider spacing out.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  FSBGs have been low (44 and 72 and 70).
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal pain: Stable, pulsitile, diffuse abdominal pain could
   represent expected post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other
   intrabdominal inflammation (such as pancreatitis), v. developing
   infection (such as chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less
   likely given that pt is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is
   stable, and she has no vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds. Morphine 1mg q4h prn for pain, but only
   to be given if clear mental status.
   -          Continue to monitor symptom and physical exam, as well as
   vitals and WBC.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   -          Repeat vanc trough in AM given changing renal status amd
   re-dose as needed.
   - OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return of
   normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Vaginal
   bleeding is scant. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped an
   appropriate 3.5 points. Hct has declined just 1 point since then,
   confirming that there is no current brisk bleed.
   -          Continue to follow q6h hct.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows atelectasis, but no sign of
   pneumonia. Phanensteil incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts
   appear normal. U/A from [**8-20**] showed 147 WBC. Urine cx from [**8-19**] was
   negative, but an infection could have developed since then.
   -          Continue to follow WBC
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative. However, hold vanc for now as level is
   supertherapeutic.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative. Urine cx from [**8-20**]
   is pending.
   -          f/u urine cx.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # Metabolic acidosis: Likely secondary to lactic acidosis from acute
   hepatic failure. ABGs show resolution: pH = 7.42.
   - D/c regular ABGs.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - d/c MgSO4, as she is now 48hrs post-delivery and hypermagnesemic
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   - Psych and SW evals today. They have been contact[**Name (NI) **].

Summary:

The patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose as a suicide attempt. She also underwent an emergency cesarean section due to pre-eclampsia. The patient's condition is complicated by respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypoglycemia, abdominal pain, anemia, leukocytosis, and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's continued elevation of liver enzymes and bilirubin levels may lead to further hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and even coma.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains tenuous, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation to support her respiratory function.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels continue to rise, and she may require continued dialysis to manage her fluid overload and electrolyte imbalance.
4. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and positive urine culture results may indicate the presence of an infection, which could worsen her condition if not treated promptly.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's frequent hypoglycemic episodes may require continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further episodes.
6. Abdominal complications: The patient's abdominal pain may be related to hepatic failure, pancreatitis, or other intra-abdominal inflammation, which could lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require transfusion therapy to prevent further complications, particularly if she experiences hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
8. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may require continued monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early.
2. Adjust the patient's treatment plan as needed to address any emerging complications.
3. Consider consulting with specialists, such as a nephrologist or a gastroenterologist, to optimize the patient's care.
4. Ensure that the patient's family is educated on her condition and treatment plan to facilitate informed decision-making.
5. Continue to provide emotional support to the patient and her family to address the psychological aspects of her condition.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a rising creatinine (Cr) level, indicating worsening kidney function. They are currently on dialysis and have been experiencing encephalopathy, which may not be solely related to liver dysfunction. The patient's mental status is unstable, and they have been sectioned by the psychiatry team, likely requiring inpatient psychiatric treatment. The patient's vital signs are not well-controlled, with abnormal laboratory values, including elevated white blood cell count (WBC), lactate, and liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The rising Cr level and worsening kidney function may lead to further complications, such as fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of infections.
2. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may worsen, leading to increased risk of seizures, coma, and death.
3. Sepsis: The elevated WBC count and lactate level may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
4. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's abnormal laboratory values, including elevated potassium and phosphorus levels, may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of central lines may increase the risk of infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) and catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs).
6. Psychiatric Complications: The patient's mental status is unstable, and they may experience worsening psychiatric symptoms, including agitation, aggression, and suicidal ideation.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's abnormal vital signs and laboratory values may indicate underlying cardiovascular instability, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and death.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory values, and medical treatment plan to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

Based on the 24-hour progress note, the patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose as a suicide attempt. She also underwent an emergency cesarean section for pre-eclampsia.

The patient's condition has been deteriorating, with increasing mental status changes, including confusion, disorientation, and impulsive behavior. She has also developed asterixis flap, which may be related to ammonia toxicity or other factors.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST) with a peak of 8370 and 373, respectively
* High AFP (77) indicating liver regeneration
* Elevated creatinine (5.5) and low urine output (10-20cc/hr)
* Hypoglycemia (requiring frequent glucose checks and repletion with amps of D50)
* Elevated phosphorous (10.1) and low ionized calcium (0.97)
* Leukocytosis (34.9) with a peak, but now slowly falling
* Anemia (likely due to post-partum, s/p c-section, dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression)

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Somnolent and confused
* Asterixis flap
* Abdominal distention and tenderness
* Respiratory failure with decreased air movement and breath sounds
* Cardiovascular stable

The patient's medical complications include:

* Renal failure with increasing creatinine and low urine output
* Respiratory failure requiring oxygen therapy
* Abdominal distention and pain
* Hypoglycemia
* Anemia
* Leukocytosis
* Elevated phosphorous and low ionized calcium
* Asterixis flap

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Infection (UTI, pneumonia, or other)
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Pancreatitis
* Chorioamnionitis
* Post-operative complications (wound infection, bleeding)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status
* Repeat head CT
* Check lactate, given increase anion gap
* Continue following daily acetaminophen levels
* Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000
* Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours
* Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec
* Continue q2h fingersticks. Give juice if sugar is low and she is awake enough to take POs
* Follow asterixis flap
* Try lactulose PO
* Repeat head CT
* Consider haldol for delirium, per psych
* Continue aluminum hydroxide, 30mg TID
* Trial off O2 by face tent
* Continue IS at least hourly
* HOB elevated
* Encourage OOB
* Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential infection
* Continue to follow Cr
* Continue to follow UOP
* Continue to follow FSBG and repletion with amps of D50
* Continue to follow hct and consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of hemodynamic or respiratory compromise

The patient's disposition is ICU care, with a code status of full.

   Micro:
   VRE rectal swab negative.
   Varicella zoster immune.
   Imaging:
   Abdominal US:
   FINDINGS: Small amount of ascites is noted in the right upper quadrant
   in the
   perihepatic region as well as in the left upper quadrant. The right
   lower
   quadrant demonstrates the largest pocket of ascites measuring
   approximately 5
   cm in depth.
   IMPRESSION:
   Four quadrant survey demonstrates a small amount of ascites with the
   largest
   pocket in the right lower quadrant measuring 5.2 cm.
   In discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 398**], the decision to perform
   diagnostic
   paracentesis was deferred in view of elevated INR (INR 3.2).
   Head CT:
   PFI: Compared to prior examination, there is more prominent effacement
   of the
   cerebral sulci especially at the convexity. The ventricles remain small
   in
   size with stable in appearance. There is no evidence for herniation. No
   hemorrhage.
   Repeat head CT:
   No interval change in degree of edema, and no new hemorrhage.
   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]). Liver enzymes have been trending
   downward, save for T bili which is still lagging. AFP was checked per
   toxicology and is high (77), indicating regeneration of liver.
   - Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
   - Repeat head CT.
   - Check lactate, given increase anion gap.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  Give juice if sugar is low and she is
   awake enough to take POs.
   # Altered mental status: Ammonia toxicity (she has an asterixis flap)
   v. diphenhydramine effect v. hypoglycemic effect (less likely given
   that she has been altered when blood sugars are normal) v. delirium
   from being in the ICU, being ill, and having very disturbed sleep v. Mg
   toxicity (but hyper- not hyporeflexic and Mg trending downward) v. low
   ionized Ca+.
   -          Follow asterixis flap.
   -          Try lactulose PO.
   -          Repeat head CT.
   -          Could try haldol for delirium, per psych. Not currently
   appropriate.
   # Elevated phosphorous: PO4 10.1, total Ca = 7.5 but ionized Ca from
   yesterday was 0.97.
   -          Aluminum hydroxide, 30mg TID.
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal distention and pain: Abdominal distention increased today.
   Tympanic centrally. Diffuse abdominal pain could represent expected
   post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other intrabdominal inflammation
   (such as pancreatitis), v. developing infection (such as
   chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less likely given that pt
   is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is stable, and she has no
   vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative.
   -          OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return
   of normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Lochia has
   picked up since getting OOB, however still not substantial enough to
   account for anemia. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped less
   than 1 point.
   -          Follow q12h hcts.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows no sign of pneumonia. Phanensteil
   incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts appear normal.
   -          Continue to follow WBC.
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   -         Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for
   depression, including inpatient hospitalization once she
s medically
   stable.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.

Summary of the patient's progress:

The patient, a 22-year-old woman, was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose. She had undergone an emergency cesarean section due to pre-eclampsia. The patient's condition has been unstable, with elevations in liver enzymes, ammonia levels, and anion gap. She has also developed respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and hypoglycemia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 34°C
* Heart rate: 191 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 139/91 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 91%
* Blood glucose: 54 mg/dL

The patient's laboratory results show:

* LFTs: ALT 1497 IU/L, AST 473 IU/L, LDH 1086 IU/L
* INR: 2.5
* Creatinine: 5.5 mg/dL
* Urea: 21.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.0 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 10.1 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver enzymes are still elevated, and she is at risk for further liver damage.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still tenuous, and she is at risk for further respiratory compromise.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is still rising, and she is at risk for further kidney damage.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is still low, and she is at risk for further hypoglycemic episodes.
5. Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is still elevated, and she is at risk for further metabolic acidosis.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient's calcium level is low, and she is at risk for further hypocalcemic episodes.
7. Hypophosphatemia: The patient's phosphorus level is low, and she is at risk for further hypophosphatemic episodes.

Plan:

1. Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
2. Repeat head CT.
3. Check lactate, given increase anion gap.
4. Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
5. Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
6. Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolytes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
7. Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec.
8. Continue q2h fingersticks. Give juice if sugar is low and she is awake enough to take POs.
9. Follow asterixis flap.
10. Try lactulose PO.
11. Repeat head CT.
12. Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs come back negative.
13. OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return of normal bowel function.
14. Follow q12h hcts.
15. Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
16. Continue to follow WBC.
17. f/u cultures.
18. Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures come back negative.
19. Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for depression.
20. Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
21. Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat breast engorgement with ice and compression.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Head CT: cerebral edema. Given mannitol.

   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]). Liver enzymes have been trending
   downward, save for T bili which is still lagging. AFP was checked per
   toxicology and is high (77), indicating regeneration of liver.
   - Continue serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
   - Repeat head CT.
   - Check lactate, given increase anion gap.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  Give juice if sugar is low and she is
   awake enough to take POs.
   # Altered mental status: Ammonia toxicity (she has an asterixis flap)
   v. diphenhydramine effect v. hypoglycemic effect (less likely given
   that she has been altered when blood sugars are normal) v. delirium
   from being in the ICU, being ill, and having very disturbed sleep v. Mg
   toxicity (but hyper- not hyporeflexic and Mg trending downward) v. low
   ionized Ca+.
   -          Follow asterixis flap.
   -          Try lactulose PO.
   -          Repeat head CT.
   -          Could try haldol for delirium, per psych. Not currently
   appropriate.
   # Elevated phosphorous: PO4 10.1, total Ca = 7.5 but ionized Ca from
   yesterday was 0.97.
   -          Aluminum hydroxide, 30mg TID.
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal distention and pain: Abdominal distention increased today.
   Tympanic centrally. Diffuse abdominal pain could represent expected
   post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other intrabdominal inflammation
   (such as pancreatitis), v. developing infection (such as
   chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less likely given that pt
   is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is stable, and she has no
   vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative.
   -          OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return
   of normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Lochia has
   picked up since getting OOB, however still not substantial enough to
   account for anemia. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped less
   than 1 point.
   -          Follow q12h hcts.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows no sign of pneumonia. Phanensteil
   incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts appear normal.
   -          Continue to follow WBC.
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   -         Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for
   depression, including inpatient hospitalization once she
s medically
   stable.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose as a suicide attempt. She also underwent an emergency cesarean section due to pre-eclampsia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurological: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, with asterixis flapping and is at risk of developing seizures. She has not been assessed for peripheral vascular, skin, or respiratory status.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, likely due to a combination of post-partum, surgical, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Her hemoglobin level is 7.5 g/dL, and her hematocrit is 20.3%.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (ARF) with a creatinine level of 5.5 mg/dL and a urine output of 10-20 cc/hr. Her urine output is low, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is elevated.
* Respiratory: The patient has respiratory failure, with decreased air movement and breath sounds at the bases. Her chest x-ray shows increased pulmonary edema and effusion.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension and pain, which may be due to post-operative pain, hepatic failure, or other intrabdominal inflammation.
* Endocrine: The patient has hypoglycemia, likely due to tylenol-induced hepatic damage. Her blood glucose levels have been frequently low since stopping D5W.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and asterixis flapping put her at risk of developing seizures.
* Infection: The patient's respiratory failure, abdominal distension, and pain may increase her risk of developing an infection.
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and pulmonary edema may increase her risk of developing ARDS.
* Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's fulminant hepatic failure may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
* Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to renal failure.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's abdominal pain and distension may be due to pancreatitis.
* Sepsis: The patient's respiratory failure, abdominal distension, and pain may increase her risk of developing sepsis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing serial neuro exams with close attention to mental status.
* Repeating head CT.
* Checking lactate levels.
* Continuing N-acetylcysteine infusion.
* Changing INR, PT, PTT, electrolytes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
* Vitamin K therapy.
* Lactulose therapy.
* Aluminum hydroxide therapy.
* Trial off O2 by face tent.
* Continue IS at least hourly.
* HOB elevated.
* Encourage OOB.
* Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential infection.
* Renal recommendations include holding off on dialysis for today, as the kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and the body is managing the fluid overload.
* Continue to follow Cr and UOP.
* Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
* Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon as the patient is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
* Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat packs) and minimize pain meds.
* Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures come back negative.
* OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return of normal bowel function.
* Follow q12h hcts.
* Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
* Continue to follow WBC.
* f/u cultures.
* Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures come back negative.
* Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for depression, including inpatient hospitalization once the patient is medically stable.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a head CT showing cerebral edema. They have been treated with mannitol and are being monitored closely for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The patient has a high anion gap, which may be related to the buildup of organic acids due to acetaminophen metabolism. They are receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for diuresis and have a central venous catheter (CVC) and arterial line (A-line) in place.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of lactate, creatinine, and liver enzymes, indicating multi-organ dysfunction. Their hemoglobin and platelet counts are low, and they have a mild anemia. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an ABG showing a normal pH, pCO2, and pO2.

The patient's neurological status is deteriorating, with no assessment of their peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic exams. They are unable to respond to stimuli, and their movement, tone, and reflexes are not assessed.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Increased ICP: The patient's cerebral edema and high anion gap increase the risk of increased ICP, which can lead to brain herniation and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's multi-organ dysfunction and elevated lactate levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can worsen their condition.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and need for CVVH indicate acute kidney injury, which can lead to further complications.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's low platelet count and elevated PT/PTT/INR suggest a coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's stable respiratory status may worsen if they develop respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponin levels suggest cardiac complications, which can worsen their condition.
7. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and anion gap suggest liver failure, which can lead to further complications.
8. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and anion gap suggest metabolic acidosis, which can worsen their condition.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with cerebral edema, requiring mannitol treatment. They have a history of acetaminophen toxicity, and liver metabolism of the drug may be contributing to high anion gap. The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to intracerebral edema and the need for diuresis. They have an RIJ CVL and A-line placed. The patient's vital signs, including hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, and respiratory support, are stable. However, the patient's neurological status is deteriorating, with no assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to cerebral edema, which may lead to brain herniation and death.
2. Worsening of anion gap, potentially causing metabolic acidosis, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Hemodynamic instability due to CVVH, which may lead to hypotension, cardiac failure, or kidney injury.
4. Infection, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which may worsen respiratory function and overall prognosis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding or stress ulceration, which may lead to hemorrhage and hypovolemic shock.
6. Electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, or hypophosphatemia, which may contribute to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or seizures.
7. Liver dysfunction, potentially leading to coagulopathy, bleeding, or encephalopathy.
8. Renal failure, which may worsen anion gap and require further interventions.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, neurological function, and laboratory results, and to adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

TEXT:
24 Hour Events:
   Head CT: cerebral edema.
   Pulled out central venous line. PICC and PIV placed.
   2u PRBCs for hct <21. Lead to 3pt bump in hct.
   CT abdomen:
   Q6H serum osm. If <320 12.5gm mannitol. Got a dose at 5pm, midnight,
   and 6:30am.
   Renal: Started on CVVH given intracerebral edema and need for diuresis.
   2 u frozen plasma were given to normalize INR prior to beginning
   hemodialysis. Goal fluid balance was 100mL more negative than the
   amount of mannitol given.
   Neurosurgery: Serial neuro exams. If pupils become fixed/dilated will
   consider surgery otherwise no need now.
   Intubated at midnight. RIJ CVL and A-line placed.
   Heme: No hemolysis. Check indirect bili and coombs test and fibrinogen
   level. (pending).
   Hepatology: Send urine organic acid as may be contributing to high
   anion gap. Apparently when liver begins metabolizing acetominophen the
   metabolites can build up organic acids and cause an anion gap.
   Off propofol for 45mins, but remained essentially unresponsive and had
   Cushingoid reflex (HTN and bradycardia).
   Repeat head CT done at 6:30am.
   Neurosurg plans to take her for placement of an ICP monitor.
   Hyperventilation to PC02 of 30, 3u FFP, fibrinogen, platelets before
   then. Maintain cerebral perfusion pressure above 70, with pressors if
   necessary.
   Renal plans to ultrafiltrate her, with goal of bringing serum osms up
   to 325.

   diphenhydramine effect v. hypoglycemic effect (less likely given that
   she has been altered when blood sugars are normal) v. delirium from
   being in the ICU, being ill, and having very disturbed sleep v. Mg
   toxicity (but hyper- not hyporeflexic and Mg trending downward) v. low
   ionized Ca+.
   -          Elevated HOB.
   -          ICP monitor to be placed this AM.
   -          FFP, platelets, cryprecipitate, hyperventilation in
   preparation of procedure.
   -          Continue mannitol.
   #Acetaminophen overdose: Leading to hepatic failure with dramatically
   elevated LFTs (peaked at ALT = 8370 and AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and
   INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]). Liver enzymes have been trending
   downward, save for T bili which is still lagging. AFP was checked per
   toxicology and is high (77), indicating regeneration of liver.
   - Continue following lactate and anion gap.
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue N-acetylcysteine 1462 mg/hr IV drip until acetaminophen
   level is undetectable and AST and ALT drop below 1000.
   - Change INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC, and LFTs checks to q 12 hours.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily per hepatology rec: will not obscure degree of
   liver function because liver will only be able to use vit K to make
   clotting factors to the degree to which it
s functional.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  Give juice if sugar is low and she is
   awake enough to take POs.
   # Anion gap metabolic acidosis:
   -          F/u labs
   # Elevated phosphorous: PO4 10.1, total Ca = 7.5 but ionized Ca from
   yesterday was 0.97.
   -          Aluminum hydroxide, 30mg TID.
   # Respiratory failure: Successfully extubated yesterday, however
   respiratory status still somewhat tenuous. Decreased air movement, and
   breath sounds at bases this AM. Chest x-ray suggests increased
   pulmonary edema v. effusion.
   -          Trial off O2 by face tent.
   -          Continue IS at least hourly.
   -          HOB elevated.
   -          Encourage OOB.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Creatinine still rising and currently 5.5. Urine output
   continuing but low (10-20cc/hr). FeNa this AM = 1.8, consistent with
   ATN from acetaminophen.
   -          Renal recommends holding off on dialysis for today, as
   kidneys are continuing to produce urine at a low rate and body is
   managing the fluid overload.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of Tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   Has been frequently hypoglycemic since stopping D5W yesterday because
   of concern for volume overload in the setting of ARF and pulmonary
   edema.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   -          Turn NG suction off then advance diet as tolerated, as soon
   as pt is consistently passing gas and having BMs.
   # Abdominal distention and pain: Abdominal distention increased today.
   Tympanic centrally. Diffuse abdominal pain could represent expected
   post-op pain v. hepatic failure v. other intrabdominal inflammation
   (such as pancreatitis), v. developing infection (such as
   chorioamnionitis). However, infection seems less likely given that pt
   is afebrile, she is normotensive, WBC count is stable, and she has no
   vaginal bleeding or exudate from wound.
   -          Continue efforts to use local comfort measures (ie heat
   packs) and minimize pain meds.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative.
   -          OOB as tolerated today, which is likely to help speed return
   of normal bowel function.
   # Anemia: Likely due to combination of post-partum, s/p c-section,
   dilutional, and stress-related bone marrow suppression. Lochia has
   picked up since getting OOB, however still not substantial enough to
   account for anemia. Pt received 1u PRBCs yesterday and hct bumped less
   than 1 point.
   -          Follow q12h hcts.
   -          Consider transfusing for hct < 20 if there are signs of
   hemodynamic or respiratory compromise.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving; peaked at 34.9 [**8-20**]. Now slowly falling. Pt
   is afebrile, so this could represent an inflammatory reaction in the
   setting of hepatic failure. CXR shows no sign of pneumonia. Phanensteil
   incision looks uninfected, as above. Breasts appear normal.
   -          Continue to follow WBC.
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative.
   # Depression: Not currently feeling suicidal, but rather just very
   embarrassed.
   -         Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for
   depression, including inpatient hospitalization once she
s medically
   stable.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   Breasts are non-tender.
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.

   Glycemic Control:  q2h FSBS.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU after a fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose as a suicide attempt. She also underwent an emergency C-section due to pre-eclampsia.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring. The potential medical complications that can arise are:

1. Increased intracranial pressure (ICP): The patient's head CT scan showed cerebral edema, and she is at risk of developing increased ICP, which can lead to brain herniation and death.
2. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which can lead to metabolic acidosis, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, which can worsen due to the development of pulmonary edema and effusion.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is rising, and she is at risk of developing AKI, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient has been experiencing frequent hypoglycemic episodes, which can worsen her condition and lead to seizures, coma, and even death.
6. Abdominal distension and pain: The patient's abdominal distension is increasing, which can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, and peritonitis.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly in the post-operative period, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
8. Depression: The patient is experiencing depression and suicidal ideation, which can worsen her condition and lead to self-harm or suicide.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which can lead to bleeding complications and increased risk of infections.
10. Anemia: The patient is experiencing anemia, which can worsen her condition and lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment with medications, fluids, and other interventions. The healthcare team should also consider involving the patient in the decision-making process and providing emotional support to help manage her depression and suicidal ideation.

   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   # Altered mental status: Likely due to elevated ICP. Underlying
   etiology remains unclear.
   -          [**Name2 (NI) 399**]ted HOB 30 degrees.
   -          ICP monitor to be placed this AM by neurosurg.
   -          Give FFP, platelets, cryprecipitate, hyperventilation (to
   PCO2 of 30) in preparation of procedure. [**Month (only) 8**] need factor VII if INR
   still > 1.5. Goal platelets >75. Goal fibrinogen >150.
   -          Check INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC q3hours. Use FFP drip,
   additional platelets, and additional cryoprecipitate to keep INR,
   platelets and fibrinogen above goals.
   -          Increase mannitol to as high as 50g q6h with osm goal of
   325. Check serum osm 1hr after mannitol.
   -          Follow post-procedure protocol provided by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**] (copy
   in chart).
   -          Continue following lactate and anion gap.
   -          Decrease NAC to 6mg/kg/hr, in case that is having unexpected
   effects on mental status.
   -          Minimize stimulation of patient.
   # Acetaminophen-induced hepatic failure: LFTs peaked at ALT = 8370 and
   AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]. Liver
   enzymes have been trending downward since then, and now even T bili is
   trending down. AFP was checked per toxicology and is high (77),
   indicating regeneration of liver. Acetaminophen level falling (7.5
   today).
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue NAC at lower dose, as above.

   -          Hyperventilate to keep PCO2 at 30.
   -          HOB elevated 30 degrees
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Cr now falling, while on CVVH.
   -          Switch from CVVH to ultrafiltration with goal of removing
   100cc more than amount of mannitol given.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   # Abdominal distention and pain: Abdominal distention slightly
   decreased today. Cause is still unclear, but likely some contribution
   from ileus and from small ascited.

   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures

s medically

   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO.
   Glycemic Control:  q2h FSBS.
   Lines: A-line, central line
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Pneumoboots, SC heparin
   Stress ulcer: Protonix
   VAP:  HOB elevated at 30 degrees. Mouth care.
   Communication: Parents here today.

24 Hour Events:
   Head CT showed cerebral edema.
   Pt pulled out her central venous line. PICC and PIV placed.
   2u PRBCs for hct <21. Lead to 3pt bump in hct.
   US abdomen: Small amount of ascites. Decision not to tap because of
   high INR.
   Intubated at 5pm. RIJ CVL and A-line placed.
   Q6H serum osm. For serum osms <20 got a 20g dose at 5pm, and a 12.5g
   dose at midnight and 6:30am.
   Renal: Started on CVVH given intracerebral edema and need for diuresis.
   2 u frozen plasma were given to normalize INR prior to beginning
   hemodialysis. Goal fluid balance was 100mL more negative than the
   amount of mannitol given.
   Neurosurgery: Serial neuro exams. If pupils become fixed/dilated will
   consider surgery otherwise no need now.
   Heme: No hemolysis based on blood smear. Check indirect bili and coombs
   test and fibrinogen level. (pending).
   Hepatology: Send urine organic acid as may be contributing to high
   anion gap. Apparently when liver begins metabolizing acetominophen the
   metabolites can build up organic acids and cause an anion gap.
   Toxicology: Check ASA level.
   Off propofol for 45mins, but remained essentially unresponsive, had
   Cushingoid reflex (HTN and bradycardia), and dilated but reactive
   pupils (1 cm).
   Repeat head CT done at 6:30am showed stable cerebral edema.
   Neurosurg plans to take her for placement of an ICP monitor.
   Hyperventilation to PC02 of 30, 3u FFP, fibrinogen, platelets before
   then. If INR is still > 1.5, give factor VII. Maintain cerebral
   perfusion pressure above 70, with pressors if necessary.
   Renal plans to ultrafiltrate her, with goal of bringing serum osms up
   to 325.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 22-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure following an acetaminophen overdose as a suicide attempt. She also underwent an emergency cesarean section due to pre-eclampsia.

The patient's condition has been unstable, with ongoing respiratory failure, anion gap metabolic acidosis, acute kidney injury, and hypoglycemia. She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation to maintain a PCO2 of 30.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, with a peak ALT of 8370 and AST of 373 at 3 am on August 21. Her INR has been elevated, reaching 8.1 at 9:22 pm on August 20. Her acetaminophen level has been falling, and she is currently receiving N-acetylcysteine (NAC) therapy.

The patient's anion gap has been improving, with a current value of 31. Her lactate level has been trending downward, and her creatinine level is falling while on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient has been experiencing abdominal distention and pain, which is thought to be related to ileus and small ascites. She has been receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and zosyn, for potential infections.

The patient's hemoglobin level has been low, with a current value of 7.5 g/dL. She has been transfused with packed red blood cells, but her hemoglobin level has not responded as expected. Her platelet count has been low, with a current value of 156, and she has been receiving platelet transfusions.

The patient's WBC count has been elevated, with a current value of 21.3. She has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and zosyn, for potential infections.

The patient's mental status has been altered, likely due to elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). She is currently intubated and sedated.

Potential medical complications that could arise in this patient include:

1. Continued decline in mental status due to elevated ICP
2. Development of sepsis or multi-organ failure due to ongoing infections
3. Progression of acute kidney injury to chronic kidney disease
4. Development of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance
5. Continued abdominal distention and pain, potentially leading to bowel obstruction or perforation
6. Development of bleeding complications due to low platelet count
7. Continued respiratory failure, potentially leading to respiratory arrest
8. Development of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy, due to liver failure

The patient's management plan includes:

1. Monitoring of ICP and cerebral perfusion pressure
2. Administration of mannitol and FFP to maintain ICP and cerebral perfusion pressure
3. Hyperventilation to maintain a PCO2 of 30
4. Continued administration of antibiotics, including vancomycin and zosyn
5. Monitoring of liver enzymes and acetaminophen levels
6. Administration of NAC therapy
7. Monitoring of hemoglobin and platelet counts
8. Transfusion of packed red blood cells and platelets as necessary
9. Monitoring of WBC count and administering broad-spectrum antibiotics as necessary
10. Continued monitoring of abdominal distention and pain, with potential for surgical intervention if necessary.

   ALT / AST:883/147, Alk Phos / T Bili:193/12.4, Amylase /
   Lipase:112/102, Differential-Neuts:93.4 %, Lymph:4.0 %, Mono:1.3 %,
   Eos:0.0 %, Fibrinogen:244 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:8.4 mmol/L, Albumin:3.3
   g/dL, LDH:598 IU/L, Ca++:13.1 mg/dL, Mg++:3.5 mg/dL, PO4:3.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   22 year old woman with fulminant hepatic failure following
   acetaminophen overdose as suicide attempt. Also s/p emergent Caesarian
   section this morning for pre-ecclampsia.
   # Altered mental status: Likely due to elevated ICP. Underlying
   etiology remains unclear.
   -          [**Name2 (NI) 399**]ted HOB 30 degrees.
   -          ICP monitor to be placed this AM by neurosurg.
   -          Give FFP, platelets, cryprecipitate, hyperventilation (to
   PCO2 of 30) in preparation of procedure. [**Month (only) 8**] need factor VII if INR
   still > 1.5. Goal platelets >75. Goal fibrinogen >150.
   -          Check INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC q3hours. Use FFP drip,
   additional platelets, and additional cryoprecipitate to keep INR,
   platelets and fibrinogen above goals.
   -          Increase mannitol to as high as 50g q6h with osm goal of
   325. Check serum osm 1hr after mannitol.
   -          Follow post-procedure protocol provided by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**] (copy
   in chart).
   -          Continue following lactate and anion gap.
   -          Decrease NAC to 6mg/kg/hr, in case that is having unexpected
   effects on mental status.
   -          Minimize stimulation of patient.
   # Acetaminophen-induced hepatic failure: LFTs peaked at ALT = 8370 and
   AST = [**Numeric Identifier 373**] at 3am on [**8-21**] and INR = 8.1 at 9:22pm on [**8-20**]. Liver
   enzymes have been trending downward since then, and now even T bili is
   trending down. AFP was checked per toxicology and is high (77),
   indicating regeneration of liver. Acetaminophen level falling (7.5
   today).
   - Continue following daily acetaminophen levels.
   - Continue NAC at lower dose, as above.
   -          Check INR, PT, PTT, electrolyes, CBC q 4 hours.
   - Vitamin K 5mg PO daily.
   - Continue q2h fingersticks.  Give juice if sugar is low and she is
   awake enough to take POs.
   # Anion gap metabolic acidosis:
   -          F/u labs ordered per hepatology.
   # Respiratory failure: Respiratory failure is linked to decline in
   mental status.
   -          Keep pt intubated until mental status clears.
   -          Hyperventilate to keep PCO2 at 30.
   -          HOB elevated 30 degrees
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn for any present or potential
   infection. However, vanc currently held for supertherapeutic level.
   # ARF: Cr now falling, while on CVVH.
   -          Switch from CVVH to ultrafiltration with goal of removing
   100cc more than amount of mannitol given.
   -          Continue to follow Cr.
   -          Continue to follow UOP.
   # Hypoglycemia: Likely a sequelae of tylenol-induced hepatic damage.
   -          Continue q2h FSBG and repletion with amps of D50.
   # Abdominal distention and pain: Abdominal distention slightly
   decreased today. Cause is still unclear, but likely some contribution
   from ileus and from small ascited.
   -          Continue vancomycin and zosyn until labs stabilize and cxs
   come back negative.
   # Anemia: No evidence for hemolysis based on smear, per hematology.
   However, pt has continued to have less than expected hct response
   following transfusion. Could be partially dilutional, as she is net
   positive 14L for her length of stay.
   -          Follow q4h hcts.
   -          Transfusing for hct < 25.
   # Leukocytosis: Improving steadily.
   -          Continue to follow WBC.
   -          f/u cultures.
   -          Continue vanc and zosyn until labs stabilize and cultures
   come back negative.
   # Depression: Difficult to assess today, as she is intubated and
   sedated.
   -          Communicate with psych regarding future treatment for
   depression, including inpatient hospitalization once she
s medically
   stable.
   # Positive U/A: However urine cx [**8-19**] was negative.
   -          Broad spectrum antibiotics (vanco and zosyn) will cover UTI.
   # s/p C-section complicated by likely pre-ecclampsia: Phanensteil
   incision is clean, without exudate or erythema. No sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring abdominal incision for sign of infection.
   - Continue monitoring breasts for mastitis/breast engorgement. Treat
   breast engorgement with ice and compression.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:
